abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: It is difficult to avoid deep surgical site infection after spinal surgery. Debridement combined with closed suction irrigation (CSI) and other treatment methods lead to greater trauma and lower satisfaction. We developed a new method for the treatment of SSI, which has the advantages of less invasiveness and lower cost. The cohort of this retrospective study comprised 26 patients with SSI after undergoing spinal surgery in our hospital from August 2017 to March 2022. The patients were divided into CSI and microtube drainage group according to treatment methods. The durations of antibiotic use and hospital stay, hospitalization costs, and functional scores during follow‐up were compared between the two groups. The only baseline characteristic that differed between the two groups was sex. Infection was controlled in both groups and there were no recurrences during follow‐up. However, the length of hospital stay after the first operation and the total length of stay were significantly greater in the CSI group. Hospitalization costs and antibiotic costs were significantly higher in the CSI group. Additionally, the duration of intravenous antibiotic use was significantly longer in the CSI group. Both the CSI and microtube drainage groups had significantly improved of Short Form Health Survey (SF‐36) scores 6 months postoperatively. However, 3 months postoperatively, SF‐36 scores were significantly lower in the CSI group. Compared with debridement followed by CSI, percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage is a more efficient and economical means of treating SSI after spinal surgery.

Ultrasound‐guided percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage versus debridement with closed suction irrigation for treating deep surgical site infection after spinal surgery. sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Surgical site infection (SSI) is the most serious postoperative complication after spinal internal fixation. SSI is difficult to treat, may take a long time to manifest, and has a high mortality rate, thus posing a major challenge to spinal surgeons. Given that the incidence of SSI after spinal surgery ranges from 0.49% to 19.1%, 1 , 2 , 3 , 4 effective treatment for it is crucial.

There have been many reports of treatment protocols for SSI; however, the efficacy of these treatments is inconsistent and there is still no consensus on the optimal treatment of SSI. 5 , 6 , 7 Surgical debridement combined with antibiotics is generally considered the main means of controlling SSI after spinal surgery. 8 , 9 However, this traditional form of treatment is both traumatic and expensive, has disastrous effects on functional recovery postoperatively, and can result in a variety of complications when multiple debridements are required. Many recent studies have reported new ways to treat SSI. Examples include meticulous debridement followed by CSI or negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) and meticulous debridement followed by antibiotics, bone cement temporary implantation, and other therapies. Despite these treatments, secondary surgery is still often required. 5 , 6 , 7 Therefore, our research team has developed a novel form of treatment for spinal SSI that obviates the need for secondary surgery, namely ultrasound‐guided percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage. In this retrospective study, we introduce this new treatment modality for deep SSI after spinal surgery and compare its efficacy with that of open debridement.

sec.title: MATERIALS AND METHODS
sec.p: This retrospective study was approved by the Ethics Review Board of Anhui Medical University. All patients had given informed consent to the treatment measures adopted during the study. The study cohort comprised all patients diagnosed with SSI after undergoing internal spinal fixation in our hospital from August 2017 to March 2022.

The inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) posterior internal spinal fixation; (2) diagnosis of incision infection after spinal surgery; and (3) treatment with CSI or percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage. Exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) follow‐up time less than 6 months; (2) delayed onset of infection (>30 days); and (3) specific infections, such as tuberculosis.

The patients were divided into a CSI group and microtube drainage group based on the treatment they had undergone for SSI. Medical records, including discharge summaries, surgical notes, laboratory test results, and complete antibiotic regimens were reviewed. Patient characteristics are summarized in detail in Table 1. Length of hospital stay, treatment costs, duration of antibiotic use, and SF‐36 scores (before admission, 3 and 6 months) were compared between the two groups.

sec.title: Treatment protocol
sec.p: The following clinical signs, symptoms, and laboratory tests were considered suggestive of post‐spinal surgery SSI: postoperative fever, gradual aggravation of lumbar nerve root irritation, deep local tenderness and percussion pain, low back and leg pain that was exacerbated by turning over and other movements, redness and swelling of the wound, fluctuation around the incision, C‐reactive protein, ESR and procalcitonin levels were abnormally elevated compared to the first day after surgery. Once spinal infection was suspected, further magnetic resonance imaging or ultrasound examination was performed for confirmation and empirically‐chosen broad‐spectrum antibiotics were administered. CSI or percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation was implemented immediately after diagnosis of spinal infection on the basis of clinical signs and symptoms and laboratory test and imaging findings. CSI was the standard procedure before we developed percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation, so all patients underwent CSI. Once we had developed percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation, a subset of patients with post‐operative spinal infections underwent the new procedure. For patients whom ultrasound examination showed a large amount of effusion at the surgical site, we chose micro‐drainage tube irrigation for treatment, while other patients chose CSI for treatment.

For patients in the microtube drainage group, bedside US examination was performed to determine the optimal site of puncture for insertion of one or more catheters. The surgical field was then routinely disinfected and covered with a sterile surgical cloth. After induction of local anaesthesia at the puncture site, an epidural needle was inserted into the infected cavity and exudate aspirated for bacterial culture and drug sensitivity testing. An epidural puncture catheter (microtube) was placed along the inner core of the needle. After removing the needle core, the microtube was secured to the skin with strong tape to prevent its detachment (Figure 1D–F). The number of microtube inserted varied on the basis of the size of the cavity. One end of each microtube was connected to a high negative pressure drainage device, after which the device was opened. When local injection of antibiotics was required, the negative pressure drainage device was clamped and the drug(s) injected via the microtube for several hours, after which negative pressure was again applied. Antibiotics were adjusted on the basis of the results of bacterial culture and drug sensitivity testing, the required agents being injected along the microtube into the infection site as needed. Changes in white cell count, C‐reactive protein, ESR and procalcitonin were monitored. The drain was removed after 3 consecutive days of almost no drainage and normal laboratory findings.

caption.p: Two cases of surgical site infection after spinal surgery were treated by two methods. (A) Appearance of surgical site exudation on day 12 after spinal fixation surgery. (B) Thorough debridement was performed to remove pus that had emerged around the internal fixation device. (C) CSI system was used after debridement. (D) Surgical site exudation occurred 4 days after spinal fixation surgery. (E) Procedure of PMDTI combined with high NPTD operation. (F) Micro‐drainage tube irrigation and high negative pressure tube drainage was treated.

sec.p: In the patients who underwent meticulous debridement followed by CSI, the debridement was performed by opening the original surgical incision. During this procedure, further specimens were collected for bacterial culture and drug sensitivity testing and the implants were checked for looseness or instability. All pus, inflammatory necrotic tissue, contaminated bone graft, and granulation tissue attached to the surfaces of the internal fixation were completely removed. The incision was washed repeatedly with a diluted iodine complex and large volumes of normal saline. One or two flushing tubes were placed at the proximal end of the incision and one or two drainage tubes at its distal end. The flushing and drainage tubes were placed across each other, and the muscles, lumbar dorsal fascia, and skin were intermittently sutured (Figure 1A–C). Antibiotic therapy was adjusted on the basis of the results of bacterial culture and drug sensitivity testing. The wound was washed daily with 8000 mL gentamicin or antibiotics to which the cultured organisms were sensitive, at a rate of 150 drops per minute. The washout time was generally about 12 h. The flushing tubes were removed once indicators of infection had resolved, including drainage fluid culture being negative on two consecutive occasions.

The timing of discharge was determined by the surgeon—generally 2–3 days after removal of the drainage or negative pressure suction tubes, provided laboratory indicators were acceptable. After discharge, all patients continued to take oral antibiotics as directed by their doctors and were followed up regularly. SF‐36 physical function scores were estimated at 3 and 6 months of follow‐up.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: IBM SPSS 25.0 software was used for data processing and statistical analysis. Normally or approximately normally distributed variables were expressed as (X ± s), and comparisons between the two groups were analysed by independent sample t‐test. χ2 tests were used to compare numerical data (categorical variables) between groups. p < 0.05 was considered to denote statistical significance.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: From August 2017 to March 2022, 801 spinal surgeries were performed in our hospital. We identified 33 SSIs among these patients, making the incidence of post‐spinal surgery SSI in our hospital during the study period 4.1%. Twenty‐six patients who met the study inclusion criteria were included in this study, 10 of whom had undergone CSI were included in CSI group and 16 percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage were included in microtube drainage group. The baseline data of the open debridement/CSI and microtube drainage groups are shown in Table 1. Age, infection site, and underlying diseases did not differ significantly between the CSI and microtube drainage groups (p > 0.05, Table 1), whereas the sex ratio did differ between these groups.

Only one patient in the CSI group had a negative bacterial culture. The bacterial cultures of two of the patients in this group revealed multiple organisms, namely Escherichia coli, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Staphylococcus aureus. The other seven patients were each infected with single organisms, E. coli in six cases and S. aureus in one. Seven patients in the microtube drainage group had negative bacterial cultures, whereas the remaining nine patients in this group were each infected with single organisms, namely E. coli, S. aureus, Enterococcus faecalis, Staphylococcus haemolyticus, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa each in one case, and Staphylococcus epidermidis in four (Table 2).

There was no significant difference in the average duration of oral antibiotics between the two groups (p > 0.05, Table 3); however, the duration of intravenous antibiotics was significantly longer in the CSI group than in the microtube drainage group (p < 0.05, Table 3). The average length of hospital stay and total length of hospital stay after the first operation were significantly longer in the CSI group than in the microtube drainage group (p < 0.05 for both, Table 3). The cost of antibiotics and total hospitalization cost were significantly higher for the CSI group than for the microtube drainage group (p < 0.05 for both, Table 3).

sec.p: All patients were followed up for 6 months, during which time no recurrences of infection were identified. There was no significant difference in SF‐36 physical function scores between the two groups at the 3‐month follow‐up or between their 3‐month follow‐up and preoperative scores (p > 0.05, Table 3). At the 6‐month follow‐up, the scores of both groups were significantly higher than the preoperative scores (p < 0.05, Table 3). There was no significant difference in SF scores between the two groups preoperatively and 6 months postoperatively; however, SF‐36 scores were significantly lower in the CSI group than in the microtube drainage group at the 3‐month follow‐up (p < 0.05, Table 3).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: The main previously reported treatment options for deep SSI are antibiotics to which the responsible organism is sensitive and thorough surgical debridement; treatment of such infections with antibiotics alone rarely being successful. 10 , 11 , 12 When conservative treatment of early deep SSIs is ineffective, especially when accompanied by progressive pain, persistent swelling, and exudation, the current consensus of most clinicians is to perform thorough surgical debridement. Localized infection is reduced by thoroughly removing wound contamination and damaged tissue and repeatedly rinsing with large amounts of hydrogen peroxide, iodophor, and normal saline. Combining this with subsequent CSI or NPWT achieves resolution of most cases of infection. However, thorough debridement by opening the surgical incision not only greatly increases the incidence of complications, but may be life‐threatening. 13

In 2019, Zeng et al. 5 reported that when they used debridement followed by NPWT to treat deep postoperative incision infections, the average length of hospital stay was more than 30 days and the duration of antibiotic use more than 60 days. Rohmiller et al. 14 reviewed the data of 28 patients with deep wound infections after posterior internal fixation fusion who had been treated with CSI. Their average hospital stay was more than 20 days and a third of them required secondary debridement. In 2014, Lian et al. 15 reported the data of 23 patients with early deep wound infection after spinal internal fixation and fusion. The average duration of CSI after debridement was 12.0 days. Second debridements and further subsequent CSI were required by 8.7% of these patients. On the other hand, placement of CSI severely limits patients' mobility and early functional exercising. Saline leakage can also impair the patient's quality of life. Although SSIs can eventually be controlled, the associated long‐term bed rest often means that patients miss out on the best time for functional exercise. This has a major negative impact on early functional rehabilitation, resulting in poor patient satisfaction. With the aim of solving these problems, we pioneered the percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage for treatment of deep infection after spinal internal fixation. This form of treatment not only achieves the same outcomes as open surgery, but also promotes early functional recovery and reduces the cost and length of hospital stay. No patient had recurrence of infection during the 6‐month clinical follow‐up or subsequent telephone follow‐up before the end of the study.

NPWT has been widely used to treat deep SSIs. 16 , 17 Negative pressure on a closed infected cavity changes the environment in which the bacteria grow, reducing their numbers and inhibiting their ability to proliferate. It also increases wound blood flow, improves local microcirculation, reduces gelatinase activity in local granulation tissue, and inhibits degradation of collagen and gelatin. 18 , 19 In addition, some studies have reported that negative pressure suction can enhance secretion of substance P and expression of calcitonin‐related gene peptides and some endogenous cytokines in peripheral nerve endings, thus promoting wound healing. 20 , 21 Furthermore, negative pressure can improve the local microcirculation by promoting capillary regeneration, which results in resolution of local edema, promoting growth of granulation tissue, and accelerating wound healing. In vitro studies conducted by Saxena et al. 22 showed that cells that have room to expand tend to divide and proliferate in the presence of soluble mitogens, whereas compressed cells remain quiescent. Studies by Timmers et al. 23 have also shown that micromechanical forces generated by negative pressure suction can stimulate wound healing by promoting cell division, angiogenesis, and natural formation of growth factors. These studies confirm the role of negative pressure in promoting wound healing. Application of NPWT after debridement has achieved good results in terms of controlling deep wound infection after spinal surgery in clinical practice. We based our treatment system on simplifying the process of applying NPWT and strengthening the local negative pressure. Our findings indicate that our system also controls deep wound infection and promotes wound healing.

Why is percutaneous catheterization alone, without rigorous debridement to remove deeply infected necrotic tissue and inflammatory exudates, able to achieve this effect? The efficacy of our system may be attributable to its early implementation. Clinicians are often very cautious about secondary surgical debridement, only considering further surgery after a period of conservative antibiotic treatment has proved ineffective. 24 However, the optimal time for treatment may by then have been missed. In 1995, Abbey et al. 25 reported treating patients with suspected deep incision infections with antibiotics alone for 4–8 weeks, then evaluating the depth of infection and instituting subsequent treatment based on the suspected severity of residual infection. Two of their patients who were assessed as having superficial infection and three with an uncertain depth of infection were later found to have deep wound infections, which seriously adversely affected their treatment and delayed resolution of infection. These researchers concluded that once a patient is suspected of having an incision infection, the best clinical outcome is achieved by actively treating it as a deep wound infection. To arrive at the correct diagnosis early and institute timely treatment, it is necessary to assess clinical signs and symptoms and laboratory test and imaging findings in the early stages after surgery. Once deep wound infection is suspected, broad‐spectrum antibiotics should be instituted promptly and further interventions selected on the basis of the results of subsequent imaging findings. Use of epidural catheters to extract fluid near to and deep to the incision and of indwelling catheters with continuous negative pressure has the advantage of enabling laboratory testing of the extracted pus or inflammatory exudate. An alternative is to wash the deep part of the incision and apply antibiotics locally through multiple puncture tubes. Moreover, this puncture method can be used both as a channel for administering local medication and for drainage, but also for early diagnosis when infection is suspected. Minimally invasive procedures such as ours allow physicians to intervene during the golden period of infection treatment and minimize the impact of SSIs on patients. When combined with antibiotics, patients can be cured without open surgical intervention, avoiding one or more reoperations.

In this study of patients with internal spinal fixation devices and postoperative infections, all who underwent catheter placement, lavage, antibiotic treatment, and continuous high negative pressure drainage were cured and there were no recurrences during the follow‐up period. percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage avoids the trauma caused by multiple anaesthetics and surgeries, reduces the patient's hospitalization costs, and achieves better functional outcomes than early open debridement. Our findings indicate that percutaneous micro‐drainage tube irrigation combined with high negative pressure tube drainage is worthy of clinical promotion and implementation. Limitations of this study include the small number of patients enrolled due to the low incidence of infection. Some enrolled patients had a clinical suspicion of infection but had a negative fine‐needle culture. Of note, our two groups of patients with infection were heterogeneous regarding the species of infecting bacteria and their sex; these factors may have impacted the findings. In future, multi‐centre studies are needed to increase the sample size. Additionally, to improve reliability, only patients with positive bacterial cultures should be eligible for these studies. In future, we plan to increase the sample size to improve the reliability of our conclusions.
